title: Leicester community groups face £363k council funding cuts - Leicester Mercury
text:
Leicester community groups face £363k council funding cuts Backbench councillors are challenging the decision Share Gorse Hill City Farm will be affected by the cuts Share Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Seven community organisations are to lose more than £350,000 in grants as Leicester City Council seeks to balance its books. 
The authority has decided to scrap annual payments made under its existing Neighbourhood Services Grant Funding scheme by 2021. 
However, some councillors representing the areas in which the affected groups operate say the decision to cut the grants has been taken without them being consulted or proper assessment of the impact. 
It is feared some of the groups, which provide valued services to many residents, could fold without council support. 
The popular Gorse Hill City Farm in Beaumont Leys is set to lose its current £64,300 grant. 
The Beaumont Lodge Neighbourhood Association gets £9,500 a year, which will be cut. It provides a hall free of charge for Beaumont Leys residents as well as breakfast clubs and a cafe. The East Park Road Sikh Community Centre’s £58,100 grant will be axed. It uses the money to provide legal advice for older residents, room hire, a pre-school and a gym, as well as English and IT classes. 
A grant of £19,100 will be removed from the St Peter’s Community Centre, in Highfields . It provides a lunch club and room hire.” 
The largest of the under-threat grants is £134,300 per year for the Wesley Hall Community Centre in Spinney Hills. 
It has provided space for the Citizens’ Advice Bureau, fitness classes and adult education as well as activities for parents and toddlers and elderly residents. 
The Saffron Lane Neighbourhood Council provides similar services for the estate, as does the Woodgate Resident’s Association, in Woodgate. They have grants of £69,400 and £8,800 respectively. Read More
